Large number of valuable lots in the City of Richmond, and in Henrico county, near to said City for sale under decrees of Court.--by virtue of a decrees of the Circuit Court of the City of Richmond, pronounced on the 22d February, 1864 in the case of Adams's administrator against Carrington, I shall us administrator do of Col Richard Adams, deceased, proceed to sall at public auction in front of the state Court-House in the City of Richmond, on Monday, the 7th March, 1864, at 12 o'clock M, such title as the estates of Richard Adams or John Adams may possess, in and to the following valuable lots, piats of which number from 1 to 17 inclusive, and filed with the papers in said cause, and be which reference is hereby mads, vis:

list.item:
No. 1.
Lots, colored yellow, marked A, B, C, d, and E, bounded by 15th, 16th, K or Clay and Pine streets, and by old mill canal.
2. A lot at the corner of Franklin and Union sts, five-six the of which was conveyed by A D Williams, and one-sixth by Samuel Wolff and wife, to Col Geo M Carrington,

3.
A trisugular lot No. 200, of the plan of the division of Richard Adam's estate, new in possession of Edward W Robinson, bounded by N, 23d, and Randolph sts.

4.
A lot, colored yellow, fronting 44 feet on Valley street, running back 165 feet to Concord st, now in possession of Va Central Railroad Company, under a deed from Anthony Robinson, Jr, and 1 A Goddin, bearing date 6th January, 1864.

5. Two lots, colored yellow, in possession of said Central Railroad Company, one fronting 51 and ten-twelfth feet on the East side of Concord street, running back 75 feet, and a triangular lot fronting 45 feet on said East side of that street, running back 75 feet.

6.
Lot, colored yellow, at the corner of Marshall and Union streets, fronting 66 feet, running back 100 feet, now in possession of said railroad company, under a deed from Jas Kinnlard.

7. Lots E F G H I, colored yellow, and bounded by 16th, and between Valley, Clay, and Marshall streets; and now in possession of Timothy C Burns, Nancy Merchant and the Virginia Central Railroad Company.
8. Lot fronting 66 feet on Washington or Green street, running back 179 8-12 feet, bounded by 16th street, as condemned by the City Council and by the Va Central railroad.

9.
Lot fronting 85 feet on Washingtons of Green street, running back an average depth of about 192 feet, bounded by the Virginia Central railroad, and now in possession of that company and of other parties.
10. Lot and larges brick tenement thereon, fronting 22 feet on the west side of Valley street, near to Marshall street, running back 120 feet to an alley, and now in possession of Jas Kinnlard

11.
Lot, colored yellow, fronting 375 feet on the south side of K or Clay streets, running back to the Lancastrian school house lot, bounded also by 14th and 15th streets, part now in possession of the heirs of Mrs Caroline M R Johnson, and the balance in controversy in the case of Crew against Ladd.

12. Lot, colored yellow, on the south side of Water street, running back to the dock, adjoining the warehouse of A S Lee and the lot of A Robinson's estate, and now partly in possession of said Robinson's heirs.

13. Being lot No. 1 of Puffing & Blackwood's plan, conveyed by Ralph Allen and others to J Adams, now in possession of the Va Central Railroad Co, bounded by I or Marshall street, 16th street, and said railroad.
14. Lot, colored red, No. 9, fronting 25 feet on the west line of Valley street, running back 90 feet, bought by the late W M Fulton, for city taxes, in the name of unknown owners.

15. Lot No. 2 of square 198, of the plan of Richard Adams's estate, now in possession of Jno P Pearson, who says that he has a patent from the Common wealth of Virginia, at the corner of K and 24th streets, fronting 132 feet, running back feet.
16. Lots Nos 2 and 3 of square No. 151 of Adams's division, each fronting feet on Cedar street, running back 132 feet, bounded by Federal and James streets, now in possession of William Whillock.

div3.p: The public and those interested are particularly referred to the decree aforesaid, and to said plats and abstracts of title accompanying said plats and surveys, (to be seen at the office of the auctioneers,) so that in bidding for said lots the facts in regard to the titles proposed to be sold may be fully ascertained.

Terms.--One third cash; balance in six and nine months, interest addle, and accrued by negotiable notes, and title retained until all the purchase money is fully paid, with the privilege to the purchaser to pay the whole purchase money in cash and get deeds at once.
The taxes for 1864 to be paid by the purchasers.
div3.closer:
Gro W Randolph,
Adm'r, &c, of Col Richard Adams, dec'd,
And Comm'r of the Circuit Court. fe 27

div3.head: By James M. Taylor, Auctioneer.

It fronts 25 feet on Broad street, and runs back 160 feet to an alley.

div3.head: One hundred dollars Reward.
div3.p:
--My servant Jesse was taken by the yankees on Brook Road, on the first day of March, with my corral mare, with four white feet, blazed face, rather over medium else, heavy with feet, and paces very easy.
I will give one hundred dollars for any information that will lead to her recovery.
div3.closer:
Wm Sledd, on Brook Road,
Near Broon Quarter Breach, mh 7--5t*

div3.head: Ran away
div3.p:
--From the undersigned, some two months since, my servant girl Agues.
She is or is years of age, light gingerbread color, and a little above medium size.
I will give a liberal reward to any one that will bring the said girl to my house, in Sidney, just above the Old Fair Grounds.
